"WAR AND THE STUDENT'

W. Van Haitsma Lectures
To Engineers On"Training The Aviator"
Speaking to approximately
125 junior and senior engineering
students Wednesday, Mr. W.
Van Haitsma delivered an illustrated lecture on "Training the
Aviator."
Mr. Haitsma, who is a representative of the Boeing School
of Aeronautics in Oakland, California, has been touring the
country delivering lectures illustrated with moving pictures. Invitations to attend the address
were sent to local engineers and
representatives of several aircraft
companies. The lecture was one
of a series of "Engineering Practice Lectures."
The next speaker in this series
is A. W. Gauger, Director Research
School of Mineral Industries of the
Pennsylvania State College. ' He
will speak on March 7.

SESSIONS START
TONIGHT AT 8:00
Relations Of Students To
War Is Subject Of
Discussion
The Sixth Annual Intercollegiate Conference on "War and the
Student" will open tonight in
Levering Hall under the sponsorship of the Johns Hopkins Liberal Club and the Goucher College L. I. D. Chapter. Students
and delegates from local organizations and neighboring colleges
are expected to attend the five
sessions of the Conference, which
features a distinguished array of
speakers who will discuss the
problems of war and their peculiar relationship to the American
student.
Friday evening's session will
be opened with a review of the
"Danger Spots in Europe" by
Katherine J. Gallagher, professor
of history at Goucher College.
Dr. Gallagher is .a graduate of
Vassar and the University of
Wisconsin and has been full professor at Goucher since 1920.
Tyler Dennett Follows

Miss Gallagher will be followed on the
platform by Tyler Dennett,
professor of in4
ternational relations at Princeton University.
Dr. Dennett who
is a distinguished
authority on the
Far East and a
—Courtesy, The Sun
former
history
DR. GALLAGHER
advisor to the
Department of State, is scheduled
to speak to the Conference on
"Storm Over Asia".
On Saturday, the convention
will meet at 10.30 a.m. to hear
Edwin Johnson, secretary of the
Committee on Militarism in Education, present various "Youth
-Attitudes Toward War."
Adjourns Until Afternoon

The next speaker will be Mr.
J. B. Matthews, chairman of the
American League Against War
and Fascism. He has chosen as
the subject of his address -"The
Dynamics of war."
Following
Mr.
Matthews
speech, the Conference will adjourn until 2 p.m. Reconvening
at that time for the third session,
the delegates will be addressed
on the subject of "Labor, Munitions, and War" by Mr. William
T. Stone. Mr. Stone is vice-president of the Foreign Policy Association and chief of its Washington Bureau.
Round Tables

The second speaker at this session will be Miss Jeanette Rankin, associate secretary of the
National Council for the Prevention of War. Miss Rankin was a
leader in the woman's suffrage
movement and has also been a
member of Congress and a leader
in the famous "Peace Lobby" at
Washington. She will discuss
"The Machinery of Propaganda."
At 4 p.m. the fourth session of
the conference will be held. It is

sent Council organization is the one which we advanced earlier ,in the year. At that time we suggested that the Council be dispensed with and
that three men—corresponding to the president and
secretary of the S. A. C. and one additional student
be appointed as a commission to be consulted by
the Dean when he draws up budgets. The petitions of any group and all possible opinions could
be adequately represented through this commission, which would not have any more power but
more advisory strength than the Council. At least
there would be less waste motion.
We may yet live to see something good come
out of this activities mess.

Campus Brevitiles

If anyone else is inclined to give the Student
Activities Council credit for finally realizing its
impotency still we must demur. Its sudden burst
of genius was entirely superimposed; if it hadn't
been forcibly borne in upon the members that
the administration seriously plans to dispense with
their function they wouldn't even have suspected
their uselessness.
However, once awakened to their actual status
they seemed completly unmanned. At the meeting
this week nothing coherent could be elicited from them
on any score. What place has the student in the control of his own activities; what organization can he
use to effect his own ends; what rules should govern
campus groups? All these issues passed unchallenged by any sort Of analytical thought. Endless
bickering and fulmination was the only manilestation of mental existence.
Activities men and others as well will simply
have to disabuse their minds of the misconception
that activities are the sole province of the students.
The insurmountable difficulty facing this idea is
that as long as the University considers itself
ultimately res'ponsible for the debts assumed by
the activities it will not be willing to relinquish
control of the financial operations. The fiction,
furthermore, of a democratic control by the students has been upset decisively. The practice of
playing fast and loose with student funds has
been so riotous under student management alone
that the intervention of the Dean has been many
times justified.
It is gratifying to observe that the plan now

myriad of little facets, it sees not one,
but a thousand worlds. Goldman's eye
is that of a class whose body is beaten
with the sting of social injustice. I ,do
not condemn Goldman because of his conditioned vision, any more than I condemn
an ant. All viewpoints are interesting—
even if they be sincere. So, likewise,
there exists another sentiment towards
college: this one belongs to a mass of
youth who bear no grudge against society—namely, to the Sons of Fortune.
Often their attitude has been expressed
through such subtle devices as snobbery
and charity; but rarely has it been. given
the respectability of an articulate form.
Here I take the opportunity to attempt
this, though I shall probably be forever
damned, in my turn, by the salt of the
earth.

THEY OF the happy harvest have
found no purpose, no ultimate, no rock—
nor do they ever expect to find such.
The sky? The stars shine coldly down.
The sand? Electrons dance and skip in
a meaningless chase. The petty threads
of life, the final pattern have no greater
thrust in the Kosmos than an ice-wagon
—and indeed, their only justification is
that by-product of happiness which far
out-weighs the accomplishment of the web
itself.
They look down from their little towers
upon a jungle of conflict, where the lions,
the upper class, dwell in state and the
mice, the proletariat, constantly sweat
to build around their masters a wall of
comfort and security. For those fortunate ones within the barrier, life holds
leadership, responsibility, and little physical work. Some keep their self-respect
at a high pitch by an occasional jowelfull of the juicy rodents. Others are
even able to so detach themselves from
the scheme of things that they sit back
and meditate over the spectacle in pure
idleness. This last lion position is considered with the greatest contempt by
voices from the lower side.
And ,that lower side, what about the
mice?' They toil, in constant competition
with the machine, adding height and
strength to the wall. In general, they
are extremely suspicious of the lions,
charging them with malicious intent in
the use of such varied media as art, boy
scout movements, and religion. They
chafe at the unhappy lot that assigned
them to be born mice—and others, no better equipped, lions. They rebel against
the illogical winds which have cast them
at the bottom of the social stack. And
their cries of misfortune sometimes float
over the barrier.

displace the mice. Few indeed will be the
tasks within to occupy the great round
of new hands. Can men be happy without work? That is a great, fundamental
problem. And there, the lions must experiment. The South Sea Islanders seem
to rejoice in pure bliss, ignorance, and
inactivity. For us remains the question
of leisure on a much higher level—a plane
of intelligence and complexity.
Perhaps the answer may be found in
creative expression—the keen development of all natural sense and capacities.
Perhaps, some new motif will be fabricated to whip men forward on the road
of existence. At any rate, it would be
wise to suggest to the proletariat just
what spiritual malestrom they are headed
fqr, before the revolution comes.
As for my brief experience in idleness,
I have found a detached life quite enjoyable. But I realize that someday when
my kidneys break down, sodden by the
heavy rains of beer; then I shall qither
commit suicide or shall be obliged to bamboozle myself with the illusion that fractured kidneys are necessary in the attainment of some higher joy. And so,
I shall probably end my days in a complex of Santa Claus, Hell, and Mother
Goose.
To sum up: the more fortunate college youth do not come to the University,
They
expecting any spiritual solace.
merely criticize the institution for not
having produced as much intellectual joy
as they had hoped for.

There can be little doubt that this man's

Relations Of Students To
War Is Subject Of
Discussion
The Sixth Annual Intercollegiate Conference on "War and the
Student" will open tonight in
Levering Hall under the sponsorship of the Johns Hopkins Liberal Club and the Goucher College L. I. D. Chapter. Students
and delegates from local organizations and neighboring colleges
are expected to attend the five
sessions of the Conference, which
features a distinguished array of
speakers who will discuss the
problems of war and their peculiar relationship to the American
student.
Friday evening's session will
be opened with a review of the
"Danger Spots in Europe" by
Katherine J. Gallagher, professor
of history at Goucher College.
Dr. Gallagher is .a graduate of
Vassar and the University of
Wisconsin and has been full professor at Goucher since 1920.
Tyler Dennett Follows

Miss Gallagher will be followed on the
platform by Tyler Dennett,
professor of in4
ternational relations at Princeton University.

is a distinguished
authority on the
Far East and a

advisor to the

"Storm Over Asia".
On Saturday, the convention
will meet at 10.30 a.m. to hear
Edwin Johnson, secretary of the
Committee on Militarism in Education, present various "Youth
-Attitudes Toward War."
Adjourns Until Afternoon

The next speaker will be Mr.
J. B. Matthews, chairman of the
American League Against War
and Fascism. He has chosen as
the subject of his address -"The
Dynamics of war."
Following
Mr.
Matthews
speech, the Conference will adjourn until 2 p.m. Reconvening
at that time for the third session,
the delegates will be addressed
on the subject of "Labor, Munitions, and War" by Mr. William
T. Stone. Mr. Stone is vice-president of the Foreign Policy Association and chief of its Washington Bureau.
Round Tables

The second speaker at this session will be Miss Jeanette Rankin, associate secretary of the
National Council for the Prevention of War. Miss Rankin was a
leader in the woman's suffrage
movement and has also been a
member of Congress and a leader
in the famous "Peace Lobby" at
Washington. She will discuss
"The Machinery of Propaganda."

the conference will be held. It is

sent Council organization is the one which we advanced earlier ,in the year. At that time we suggested that the Council be dispensed with and
that three men—corresponding to the president and
secretary of the S. A. C. and one additional student
be appointed as a commission to be consulted by
the Dean when he draws up budgets. The petitions of any group and all possible opinions could
be adequately represented through this commission, which would not have any more power but
more advisory strength than the Council. At least
there would be less waste motion.
We may yet live to see something good come
out of this activities mess.

Campus Brevitiles

If anyone else is inclined to give the Student
Activities Council credit for finally realizing its
impotency still we must demur. Its sudden burst
of genius was entirely superimposed; if it hadn't
been forcibly borne in upon the members that
the administration seriously plans to dispense with
their function they wouldn't even have suspected
their uselessness.
However, once awakened to their actual status
they seemed completly unmanned. At the meeting
this week nothing coherent could be elicited from them
on any score. What place has the student in the control of his own activities; what organization can he
use to effect his own ends; what rules should govern
campus groups? All these issues passed unchallenged by any sort Of analytical thought. Endless
bickering and fulmination was the only manilestation of mental existence.
Activities men and others as well will simply
have to disabuse their minds of the misconception
that activities are the sole province of the students.
The insurmountable difficulty facing this idea is
that as long as the University considers itself
ultimately res'ponsible for the debts assumed by
the activities it will not be willing to relinquish
control of the financial operations. The fiction,
furthermore, of a democratic control by the students has been upset decisively. The practice of
playing fast and loose with student funds has
been so riotous under student management alone
that the intervention of the Dean has been many
times justified.
It is gratifying to observe that the plan now

not condemn Goldman because of his conditioned vision, any more than I condemn
an ant. All viewpoints are interesting—
even if they be sincere. So, likewise,
there exists another sentiment towards
college: this one belongs to a mass of
youth who bear no grudge against society—namely, to the Sons of Fortune.
Often their attitude has been expressed
through such subtle devices as snobbery
and charity; but rarely has it been. given
the respectability of an articulate form.
Here I take the opportunity to attempt
this, though I shall probably be forever
damned, in my turn, by the salt of the
earth.

THEY OF the happy harvest have
found no purpose, no ultimate, no rock—
nor do they ever expect to find such.
The sky? The stars shine coldly down.
The sand? Electrons dance and skip in
a meaningless chase. The petty threads
of life, the final pattern have no greater
thrust in the Kosmos than an ice-wagon
—and indeed, their only justification is
that by-product of happiness which far
out-weighs the accomplishment of the web
itself.
They look down from their little towers
upon a jungle of conflict, where the lions,
the upper class, dwell in state and the
mice, the proletariat, constantly sweat
to build around their masters a wall of
comfort and security. For those fortunate ones within the barrier, life holds
leadership, responsibility, and little physical work. Some keep their self-respect
at a high pitch by an occasional jowelfull of the juicy rodents. Others are
even able to so detach themselves from
the scheme of things that they sit back
and meditate over the spectacle in pure
idleness. This last lion position is considered with the greatest contempt by
voices from the lower side.
And ,that lower side, what about the
mice?' They toil, in constant competition
with the machine, adding height and
strength to the wall. In general, they
are extremely suspicious of the lions,
charging them with malicious intent in
the use of such varied media as art, boy
scout movements, and religion. They
chafe at the unhappy lot that assigned
them to be born mice—and others, no better equipped, lions. They rebel against
the illogical winds which have cast them
at the bottom of the social stack. And
their cries of misfortune sometimes float
over the barrier.

displace the mice. Few indeed will be the
tasks within to occupy the great round
of new hands. Can men be happy without work? That is a great, fundamental
problem. And there, the lions must experiment. The South Sea Islanders seem
to rejoice in pure bliss, ignorance, and
inactivity. For us remains the question
of leisure on a much higher level—a plane
of intelligence and complexity.
Perhaps the answer may be found in
creative expression—the keen development of all natural sense and capacities.
Perhaps, some new motif will be fabricated to whip men forward on the road
of existence. At any rate, it would be
wise to suggest to the proletariat just
what spiritual malestrom they are headed
fqr, before the revolution comes.
As for my brief experience in idleness,
I have found a detached life quite enjoyable. But I realize that someday when
my kidneys break down, sodden by the
heavy rains of beer; then I shall qither
commit suicide or shall be obliged to bamboozle myself with the illusion that fractured kidneys are necessary in the attainment of some higher joy. And so,
I shall probably end my days in a complex of Santa Claus, Hell, and Mother
Goose.
To sum up: the more fortunate college youth do not come to the University,

Carries On Secretly

Mr. Easley gives the impression,
it was stated, that the N. S. L. carries on its activities surreptitiously
and shows a photostated copy of the
Student,Review, the organization's
magazine. It was pointed out that
at Hopkins anyone can find a copy
of that magazine on the readingroom shelf. A few of the individual chapters are at present secret because "bigoted" administration officials refuse to allow them
to meet openly.
The Hopkins spokesman said he
regretted that Mr. Easley had to
put his attack on the "low plane of
name-calling" instead of trying to
criticize the policies and activities
of the National Student League.
Its work on the campus, so far,
he described as having consisted of
helping to reopen the city night
schools in a city-wide campaign,
carried on in cooperation with other
organizations such as the Social
Problems Club and members of the
Liberal Club.
